user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SetSocketDefaultFlags_Impl:
```c
void OS_SetSocketDefaultFlags_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;
    int                             os_flags;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    os_flags = fcntl(impl->fd, F_GETFL);
    if (os_flags == -1)
    {
        /* No recourse if F_GETFL fails - just report the error and move on. */
        OS_DEBUG("fcntl(F_GETFL): %s\n", strerror(errno));
    }
    else
    {
        os_flags |= OS_IMPL_SOCKET_FLAGS;
        if (fcntl(impl->fd, F_SETFL, os_flags) == -1)
        {
            /* No recourse if F_SETFL fails - just report the error and move on. */
            OS_DEBUG("fcntl(F_SETFL): %s\n", strerror(errno));
        }
    }

    impl->selectable = true;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no fragments that modify the function parameter or the pointer itself. Details:
- The parameter is declared as const OS_object_token_t *token; the code only dereferences it to obtain a value (*token) for OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET and does not assign to *token or to token itself.
- There is no statement reassigning token or writing through token; only reads occur from the token.
- The subsequent operations (fcntl calls, errno/strerror, OS_DEBUG) do not modify the parameter.
- The assignment impl->selectable = true modifies the file-record pointed to by impl (obtained from the global table), not the function parameter or the object pointed to by token; modifying objects reachable via other means is allowed under the rule.

Therefore, no code fragments need investigation for violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 in this function.
